text: Can I just check why would, `sum(r.total_matched for r in market_book.runners)` not equal `market_book.total_matched`. I'm getting discrepancies and I have also notices that r.total_matched is moving up and down as time progresses. I had assumed r.total_matched is the total matched for that runner and as such should only increase as time progresses. If it isn't - is there an method or attribute that can be called from the runners class that has the total matched for that runner?

elements.text: Can I just check why would,
sum(r.total_matched for r in market_book.runners)
not equal
market_book.total_matched

text: Currency fluctuations can cause changes, is this data from betfair? Someone else had this issue a while ago

elements.text: Currency fluctuations can cause changes, is this data from betfair? Someone else had this issue a while ago

text: Its when I run backtests on the historic data I have purchased from Betfair. It's on every event (all horse races) and it isn't like its when the market is forming either. I am usually only testing the last 5 minutes before the start of the event. I was wondering if `r.total_matched` wasn't actually the total matched for the runner but was something else. `market_book.total_matched` seems accurate and behaves as expected.

r.total_matched

text: Ah I remember, its because the runner total matched is a delta? Which is different to the live stream

text:
Below is a print I am getting using two different code blocks to calculate the total matched and the marketbook.total_mathced method
Method 1: `sum(r.total_matched for r in market_book.runners)`
Metho2:
```for r in market_book.runners:
    manual.append(r.total_matched)
    #manual is a list that later gets summed and printed```
The print of the outputs is as follows:
*Seconds to start:* 288.873 *Event_id:*1.146453529  *Method1:* 21568 *Method2:* 21568 *marketbook.total_matched:*192211.84

I did consider they might be deltas but if they are deltas then marketbook.total_matched t+1 should equal marketbooktotal_matched t0 plus the deltas (method1 t0 or method2 t0) from the previous line. But as you can see from the two sequential prints below it doesn't.

*t0:         Seconds to start:*286.647 *Event_id:*1.146453529 *Method1:* 28377.43 *Method2:* 28377.43 *marketbook.total_matched:*193643.97
*t+1:*      *Seconds to start:*286.573 *Event_id:*1.146453529 *Method1:*29856.27 *Method2:*29856.27  *marketbook.total_matched:* 193658.99

text: Hi, after a couple of internet issues at home, I guess the best way forward is to hire a VPS. Tried a few "low cost" shops (vultr, OVH and etc), but the servers/IPs there were restricted by betfair saying it is in a country "from where we do not accept bets from".  I was wondering what was the best thing to do. Should I contact Betfair using the Ray ID given on the above warning message, or should I just try another VPS shop hoping to have an IP able to access the betfair site? Any advices/pointers will be appreciated. Thanks!

I was wondering what was the best thing to do. Should I contact Betfair using the Ray ID given on the above warning message, or should I just try another VPS shop hoping to have an IP able to access the betfair site? Any advices/pointers will be appreciated. Thanks!

text:
Regarding the issue I had this morning regarding `r.totalmatched`  I am still trying to solve a raft of other issues associated with the problem. Gone over a few of the pro files I purchased from BF and they seem to have more than a few anomalies.
1. The first market update in each event seems to indicate money is already matched on the market. More odd is that no money appears to be matched on any of the runners
2. Whenever money is matched on a runner that delta is not what's added to the total amount matched on the market, which always goes up but by a different amount. 
3. Sometimes total amount matched on the market goes up without any runner receiving a delta. 
Very hacked off, its pro data that cost me some trading revenues. Wasn't expecting this, useless in its current form for what I have in mind. I have run the same code over files recorded with flumine and there are no issues. Also looking through flumine recorded files and the values for total matched on the market accurately reflect the sum of the amounts matched on each runner.

elements.text: Regarding the issue I had this morning regarding
r.totalmatched
I am still trying to solve a raft of other issues associated with the problem. Gone over a few of the pro files I purchased from BF and they seem to have more than a few anomalies.
The first market update in each event seems to indicate money is already matched on the market. More odd is that no money appears to be matched on any of the runners
Whenever money is matched on a runner that delta is not what's added to the total amount matched on the market, which always goes up but by a different amount.
Sometimes total amount matched on the market goes up without any runner receiving a delta.

Very hacked off, its pro data that cost me some trading revenues. Wasn't expecting this, useless in its current form for what I have in mind. I have run the same code over files recorded with flumine and there are no issues. Also looking through flumine recorded files and the values for total matched on the market accurately reflect the sum of the amounts matched on each runner.

text: I have a feeling it's not exactly what you expect...

elements.text: I have a feeling it's not exactly what you expect...

text:
Maybe its just that the data is not normally distributed (and very noisy) so your standard deviation of the residuals are all over the shop?
I'm certainly no stats expert though..

elements.text:
Maybe its just that the data is not normally distributed (and very noisy) so your standard deviation of the residuals are all over the shop?
I'm certainly no stats expert though..

text: Whew, okay finally got to the bottom of it. I think it's a degrees of freedom thing.

elements.text: Whew, okay finally got to the bottom of it. I think it's a degrees of freedom thing.

text:
I never understand degrees of freedom well and maybe I'll read through a proof at some point or whatnot, but basically, the rmse reported by the R lm() function accounts for degrees of freedom, which changes the denominator slightly in the equation.

The additional variable added so little information that the degrees of freedom thing causes the RMSE to actually get worse.

When I do a rawish RMSE calculation manually, not doing degrees of freedom, I get numbers that look very similar, as we'd expect, but they do show the slight improvement in RMSE.

elements.text:
I never understand degrees of freedom well and maybe I'll read through a proof at some point or whatnot, but basically, the rmse reported by the R lm() function accounts for degrees of freedom, which changes the denominator slightly in the equation.

The additional variable added so little information that the degrees of freedom thing causes the RMSE to actually get worse.

When I do a rawish RMSE calculation manually, not doing degrees of freedom, I get numbers that look very similar, as we'd expect, but they do show the slight improvement in RMSE.

text: "vps"  yep they nailed computing in the 60s with the mainframe. But there's no money in dumb terminals so we've had 50+ years of consumerism telling us we all need more powerful and expensive kit at home. But now we can all run a nuclear powerstation form the back bedroom and don't need even better, what a suprise the Emporer of Silicon Valley comes along with is new "cloud" and "vps" range of clothes.  Same with software, now we all have Excel v865 they want us to rent it on a "cloud" rather than get us to buy Excel v866 with added pontless stuff.  Tech has taken a 50yr ride on the moneygoround and ended up exactly where it started! Nurse! I think I need one of my pills:expressionless:
